search_result.title: Frustrated by what he saw, police officer cleaning up Wilmington
search_result.text:
Bishop Thomas Wesley Weeks Sr. relocated his church to Wilmington's Lower Brandywine Village neighborhood about 12 years ago to be an agent of change in an area plagued by poverty and violence.

But as New Destiny Fellowship Church worked to create that change, Weeks found himself discouraged and embarrassed by the amount of trash and debris appearing around the building at 906 16th St.

Piles of construction debris would regularly appear near the church. There was a time someone discarded the remnants of a foreclosed house and there were always mounds of tires greeting worshippers on their way to God's house.

"Nobody wants to be around when there's trash," Weeks said. "You don't feel at ease and you certainly don't feel like someone is paying attention. So it's very discouraging as we're trying to get people involved."

Recently, Weeks said he's noticed a reduction in the amount of trash around the church and the neighborhood. He attributes it to a partnership with Wilmington officials, especially city police Patrolman Nick Kroll, who since December has been stepping up efforts to stop much of the blight he comes across.

Kroll said when he joined the department about four years ago he was all about catching bad guys and dealing with the drugs and guns plaguing some of the city's neighborhoods. But as time went on, he noticed that the trash, which affects everyone's quality of life, was not being addressed.

"For me, it was just exhausting to see and frustrating," said Kroll, assigned to Wilmington's northeast part of town. "While there are a lot of other things going on in the city, this is important from a quality of life and a financial standpoint."

"It was just so gross and overdone," he said.

STORY: Purzycki unveils plan to 'stabilize' Wilmington's West Center City

STORY: 10-11 tons of trash removed from Delaware beaches every day

Kroll partnered with the city's Department of Public Works in going after people illegally dumping in these communities. This partnership has allowed the city to file criminal charges against many of them.

Before Kroll got involved, illegal dumping usually resulted in a $50 fine – if the perpetrators were caught. The low fine emboldened some to risk getting caught dumping, rather than paying the landfill fee, which can start at $85 per ton for people without a discount disposal fee.

Kroll knows this because of what he was nonchalantly told by people he arrested.

"Probably half of them said, 'Well everyone else is doing it there,' " Kroll said.

"The chances of them getting identified and picked up before we started this investigation was slim to none," he said. "So you had these contractors rolling the dice and they just back up and unload their trucks."

Kroll not only brings his investigative skills to these matters, he's able to file criminal charges that carry stiffer penalties, including having illegal dumpers reimburse what it costs Wilmington to clean up their messes.

During two recent clean-ups on Hay Road, the city collected about 140 tons of trash and debris. That clean-up cost Wilmington about $86,000 to dispose of in the landfill – not including the man hours or the costs of equipment.

So far, Kroll has arrested 20 people and one of the things he found interesting was that 17 don't live in the city.

"Officer Kroll has tackled an ongoing illegal activity in our city that is traditionally hard to control," Wilmington Mayor Mike Purzycki said. "We have to work hard to keep our city clean and beautiful. And as the officer's outstanding work confirms, the majority of those who dump trash in our city, don’t live in our city.

"We are striving for excellence in public service in Wilmington and Officer Kroll, with the support of staff from city public works department, exemplifies how to get things done effectively," said Purzycki.

The mayor thanked Kroll "for sending a message to would-be violators that Wilmington is a lot smarter than they are and we'll arrest and prosecute them if they trash our city."

Public works officials said they are seeing less littering in some of these areas.

"The kid is just doing a great job with it," said Marlyn W. Dietz, Wilmington's public works director of operations.

Dietz said Kroll's efforts have been contagious.

"At first, the other officers were busting on him, calling him the 'trash police,' " Dietz said. "But once they started seeing that he was making some headway, they started giving him information. So it's kind of been like a snowball growing."

Kroll effort started at a time Dietz was trying to get more help in controlling the problem himself. Dietz bought more cameras to catch people dumping trash and enlisted the help of state parks officials to show him how to set up the cameras.

Dietz, a former city police officer with more than 30 years on the force, said he'd like to have Kroll assigned exclusively to this.

"His enthusiasm is energizing to see it because it makes us want to do more now," he said. "It makes me want to get more cameras. It makes me want to try and get him here on a more permanent basis."

Wilmington Police Chief Robert Tracy said the department is committed to working in conjunction with other city departments to help increase the quality of life within of residents.

"Throughout numerous geographical areas of the city, citizens complaints have been made known to us in reference to illegal dumping incidents," Tracy said. "Officer Kroll of our Uniform Services Division has been an integral part of an initiative to investigate and arrest those individuals who use our city as a dumping ground, the vast majority identified thus far don't even reside in our city."

Tracy said the department will continue to communicate with Wilmington residents and businesses to address these types of issues, adding that police are a key factor in the city's revitalization efforts.

"The community is and will continue to be an integral part of our policing initiative success," he added.

While Weeks has not met Kroll, he had nothing but praise for the officer's work to improve the community's quality of life.

"People may not know him personally and pat him on the back, but his work speaks for him," Weeks said, adding it encourage others to get involved and better care for their community. "That's what needs to happen throughout the whole city, is that we see police officers take a real interest in the community. It helps fortify where people are at."

"Once people see they have partners in this, they step up to the plate," he said. "In a lot of neighborhoods, people are willing to step up to the plate. They just want to see that the city, the police and the other departments want to."

Contact Esteban Parra at (302) 324-2299, eparra@delawareonline.com or Twitter @eparra3.

search_result.title: Wilmington program could breed jobs
search_result.text:
Christina Jedra

The News Journal

The entrepreneurship training model started in St. Paul has been replicated in Detroit, Syracuse, Albany and Philadelphia.

When Angelica Morales started cleaning houses for a living, she didn't have a business plan.

The 43-year-old Mexican immigrant had just sold her food store in Wilmington's Hilltop neighborhood after an armed robbery, and she didn't know where to turn.

"I was scared, but I knew I had to pay my bills," she said.

She started Angelica's Housekeeping in 2010, advertising with thousands of hand-placed flyers. Working with the help of her family, she's been able to pay her bills, but now she wants to grow her business.

Morales is one of two dozen students who have been taking classes through Launcher, a new entrepreneurship initiative started by West End Neighborhood House. Each week for 12 weeks, students hoping to start, expand or stabilize their businesses meet for workshops in topics like financial planning, marketing and business law.

"I don't want someone to just have a certificate," said Michael McCafferty, the program director. "I want them to have businesses."

To do that, the students – half in Wilmington, half in Claymont – will get continued support. After graduation this month, they will have access to topic-specific workshops taught by local experts, loans and credit options from the Community Development Financial Institution and a business incubator with shared office space to cut costs and facilitate collaboration.

Participation was free for students, thanks to a $900,000 contribution from Barclays, which will fund three years of the program. The only requirement is that they either live or open businesses in their Launcher community, either on the west side of Wilmington or in Claymont.

The program's goal is to launch 40 businesses and create 150 jobs in three years. Some of those new businesses could help occupy some of the 1,500 vacant buildings in Wilmington.

"When someone starts a business in the neighborhood, they’re going hire in the neighborhood," McCafferty said. "The idea is that you prop up those communities with small businesses."

A proven method

The Launcher program uses a blueprint formulated in St. Paul, Minnesota, in the 1990s. At the time, businesses were suffering, and wooden boards covered up former bakeries, law offices and markets. Officials realized the traditional method of asking established businesses to fill vacancies wasn’t working, said Mihailo Temali, founder of the Neighborhood Development Corp. in St. Paul.

"These neighborhoods had a reputation of being old, dying and dangerous," Temali said. "It didn’t have the space or appearance that successful businesses wanted anything to do with."

Temali and his colleagues had a “light bulb moment": There were already hundreds, if not thousands, of people in those neighborhoods running small-scale businesses often without the business plan, financing and connections it took to "bring the business above ground." Revitalization, they realized, is less likely to come from an outside corporate savior than from an investment in the people already there.

"And that had to start with education," Temali said.

They started hosting training classes to help entrepreneurs write business plans. The classes were hosted in the community and were taught by local business owners the students already knew and trusted.

"Getting into business is a frightening thing for anybody who has half a brain," Temali said. "If you’re not from a family or community that has experience doing that, it's very unnerving. To do it in a small group with folks from your own community, and you’ve got a trainer from that community that’ll guide you, that’s a different kind of an offering."

The first class in St. Paul graduated with pride, and the students were motivated to start work, Temali said.

"And then we looked at each other said: Who’s going to get them a loan?"

So they added another component to the class: coordinating with banks.

Twenty-three years later, Temali's program has trained 5,000 low-income, mostly minority residents, launching about 1,000 businesses, about 450 of which are still in place today in some of St. Paul's poorest neighborhoods, Temali said.

The effect is creating a generation of role models, and the return of hope, Temali said.

"People start believing and can pivot a negative perception of a community to a positive one," he said. "In sports, they call it momentum. If you've got a team losing all the time, their heads always down, nobody goes to the game because you know they’re going to lose. The opposite is also true."

The results are tangible: For every $1 spent on Neighborhood Development Center programs targeting inner-city entrepreneurs, $28 is returned every year to the neighborhoods through payroll, rent, taxes and other expenditures, according to a 2012 commissioned evaluation of Neighborhood Development Center by Wilder Research, an organization that assesses social impacts.

Sixty percent of the supported new businesses in St. Paul fill a formerly vacant property, helping to transform blighted neighborhoods, Temali said. Some businesses, like barbershops or coffee shops, also provide new community gathering places.

Some St. Paul neighborhoods with business investment have seen crime lowered, Temali said.

"I’m not the guy out there at 8 o'clock at night doing anything to bring down crime, but maybe the hair salon or baker is," Temali said. "They’re the ones on the front lines."

A business plan for Wilmington

During a class on accounting last week, students listened intently to instructor Jerome Stanley, owner of the Simply Styling hair salon in Wilmington.

"(Entrepreneurs) fall into the trap of not taking the business of their business seriously," he told the class. "Anybody can make a glass of water, but if you don’t know how to manage that glass of water and use the right accounting, then you’re going to have a problem."

In that classroom, the students' goals are diverse. Michael L. Lewis Jr. is trying to develop his handcrafted bow tie business. Jeremy Hebbel, co-owner of the event management company Gable Music Ventures, wants to expand the scope of the Ladybug Festival, a female-focused music event.

“We’ve been doing the event for five years – without a business plan," Hebbel said. "It was interesting to come in and be like, wow, we really should’ve done this at the beginning.”

One of the students, Nasaii Oliver, is only 15. He started his lemonade business when he was 12, setting up a stand at Jessup Street and Vandever Avenue.

"I was already selling it person to person, and now I want to wholesale it," he said.

Kenisha Sutherland, who goes by the name Chef ThugLife, wants to open a sandwich shop on the west side of Wilmington. The well-traveled 24-year-old said she wants to bring the flavors of the world to the city.

"There are certain things that people in Wilmington don’t get to experience because they don’t see certain things," she said. "I want to be able to bring flavors from different countries and different places I go and bring that back to Wilmington to show people, this flavor came from here."

McCafferty said he is looking forward to the next step for the inaugural class, reaching out to lenders.

"By the time you’ve put all these weeks together, now you’ve got a business plan, and that’s what we want. That’s the business plan I can take to the banks and some of the funders."

The program has the support of local officals. Gov. John Carney, County Executive Matt Meyer and Mayor Mike Purzycki spoke at a kickoff event on Tuesday. Purzycki commended the entrepreneurs on taking a risk.

"To go out there and do it yourself, everyone needs a little help," Purzycki said. "It's nice to have someone to give you a start. That's important."

Since starting Launcher, Morales said she has already made big changes to her business. Angelica's Housekeeping has become Angelica's Cleaning Service to welcome commercial clients. She's exploring her options for accounting and insurance, writing a formal business plan to present to banks and marketing herself.

"Now we don’t park our car in the (customer's) driveway," she said, showing off her new branded uniform. "I park on the street so that people can see."

Applications for future programs can be submitted through LauncherDE.org.

Contact Christina Jedra at cjedra@delawareonline.com, (302) 324-2837 or on Twitter @ChristinaJedra.

search_result.title: Equal Justice Initiative founder Bryan Stevenson honored by Time ...
search_result.text:
Months after Equal Justice Initiative opened its internationally lauded lynching memorial, EJI founder Bryan Stevenson has been named one of Time Magazine's "31 People Changing the South."

Time included the list, which tapped leaders in fields from evangelicalism to the culinary arts, in a special South issue dedicated to "the stories, lives and history behind the country’s most culturally complex region."

More:What visitors from across the country said after visiting EJI's lynching memorial

"In the heart of the South, Stevenson detects progress," Karl Vick writes in Time. "He notes that the lynching memorial met far less local resistance than his earlier project in a city cluttered with monuments to the Confederacy, to place plaques at former slave markets. All whites approach this subject with apprehension, while some fear of bearing blame."

Stevenson told Vick he has "no interest" in using the memorial to punish people for history.

"I want to liberate us," Stevenson said. "I think people fear because they don’t understand what’s on the other side. We are not just slave states in the American South. We are not just lynching states. We are not just segregation states. We are more than that. The people are more than that. The region is more than that. But we can’t ignore this part of our history that we have been so reluctant to address if we want to be seen as we truly are.”

More:An era of terror: Montgomery family remembers father's lynching, legacy

Stevenson moved to Montgomery in 1989 to help run an arm of a civil rights group specifically focused on death penalty defense cases. He eventually founded the Equal Justice Initiative, which continued Stevenson's focus on death penalty defense as well as working to overturn several prominent wrongful convictions.

As EJI grew, so did its mission. It now acts as an advocacy arm for its criminal justice work, in addition to producing research on poverty and racial injustice.

More:After the opening of the lynching memorial, what comes next?

EJI's research began to build the framework for the lynching memorial and museum, which opened with star-studded fanfare in April. The sobering memorial sits atop a six-acre site on Caroline Street in the Cottage Hill neighborhood in downtown Montgomery, with an austere steel column representing every county in the country where a black person was lynched. Each victim's name is carved in the metal.

"I think this is both the tragedy and I guess the exciting thing about this, you ask anybody in this country to name one African-American lynched between 1877 and 1950, and they can’t give a single name," Stevenson told the Advertiser earlier this year.

Editorial:Our shame: The sins of our past laid bare for all to see

"We have no consciousness about this history. None. In that respect as we begin to tell these stories — as we are able to say Elizabeth Lawrence was lynched in Birmingham, Wes Johnson was lynched in Abbeville — that for me is success. I think we are being quite clear about our desire to change the landscape.

search_result.title: 'Justice for All': Black History Month program highlights need for ...
search_result.text:
Rebecca Burylo

Montgomery Advertiser

When the Honorable Bryan Stevenson was just a boy, he and his sister had never swam in a swimming pool.

Both students of an integrated Delaware public school in the 1970s, they couldn't wait to leave on their class trip to Orlando's Disney World. Not so much to visit with Disney's characters brought to life, but to swim at the hotel's pool. The day that should have been an unforgettable memory of joy as they splashed into the waters was quickly soured forever — all because they were black.

Stevenson recounted the memory to a packed congregation Sunday afternoon for the annual Laymen's Fellowship Black History Program hosted by the First Congregational Christian Church. His theme was "Justice for All."

White families began screaming and yanking their children out of the pool as one man turned to a confused Stevenson who asked what was wrong. "You're wrong," the man said and humiliated Stevenson by using a racial slur.

It was just one of several stories Stevenson told about his own upbringing and professional experiences that prove America must change its narrative about racism, Stevenson said. The nation's great evil was not slavery, but rather the "ideology of white supremacy" he said and in order to bring about true freedom for the African American community it must be confronted.

As the founder and executive director for the Equal Justice Initiative in Montgomery, he has become recognized worldwide as a public interest lawyer who works to defend the poor, the incarcerated, the condemned and "the broken." He was named by Time Magazine as one of the 100 most influential people in the world and served on President Barack Obama's Task Force on 21st Century Policing.

He began his message by saying that the work of bringing about true justice for the black community it not done. While they can celebrate successes such as electing the first black president and having more black trial judges and black professionals in Montgomery's history, there is still a broken justice system and systematic racism that must be dealt with he said.

Nationwide, the number of inmates in prison has grown from 300,000 in 1972 to 2.3 million, 6 million people are currently on probation or parole and 70 million people have been arrested, marring their chances of getting a job or voting — many of whom are black — Stevenson said.

"People came, the president came in 2015 to march across the Edmund Pettus Bridge. They wanted to commemorate the historic march that led to the Voting Rights Act and it was glorious to see, but most of them had no idea that when they crossed that bridge and left Montgomery, they were leaving a state where 30 percent of the black male population has permanently lost the right to vote because of a criminal investigation," Steven said.

"Our silence means there is more work to be done."

He challenged the crowd to become uncomfortable in that work of bringing about more positive change.

Stevenson's greatest concern is that those, like the families who yanked their children out of the pool after he and his sister jumped in, are not having the same discussions as he and others are who are fighting for equal justice. If discussions are not made across the board, change cannot happen he said.

"We have a identify crisis in this country. I don't think we're free," Stevenson said. "We can do things our forefathers couldn't do, but we are burdened by our history of racial inequality. It's like smog. It's in the air and we've been breathing it our whole lives.

"It's created barriers to overcome and we haven't talked about things that we need to talk about like the genocide of the Native Americans through our wars, famine and disease. We used racial difference to justify it, just like the same racial narrative was used to justify slavery."

In order to truly be free, he told the audience to make sure the decades of terrorism from the Klu Klux Klan, the lynchings, the slave trading in Montgomery and the beatings are openly talked about. That's why Stevenson's EJI is building a memorial in Montgomery devoted to 4,075 African Americans who were killed by lynching from 1877 to 1950 according to the nonprofit's research.

Plans are also underway to open a museum near the memorial in downtown Montgomery that tells the history of blacks in America from slavery to the present.

His charge Sunday was to be committed to the cause.

"I don't know of any time in history when the fight against things that were not right, was comfortable," he said. "Let's be committed to caring for our poor and our incarcerated ... only then can we be free."

search_result.title: Equal Justice Initiative considers expansion downtown, retail space ...
search_result.text:
The rolling success of the Equal Justice Initiative's museum and memorial may soon bring more downtown expansion.

The Montgomery City Council approved the sale of a parking lot downtown near Riverwalk Stadium for $900,000 to the civil rights nonprofit. City officials said at their City Council work session that the group is looking to possibly add a restaurant, more retail space and a bus shuttle location.

The city would commit $150,000 of the sale to street and lighting improvements in the area, said Mac McLeod, head of development, adding that EJI is expected to spend another $1 million in the area.

“One of the things they talked about, they could have some more exhibit space but also be able to have a book store there to have some merchandise,” Mayor Todd Strange said.

The council voted on the sale at Tuesday’s full meeting, but their approval will not guarantee a final sale. The nonprofit has 30 days to back out of the deal and 30 days to close. If all goes according to plan, McLeod said construction would likely begin at the beginning of 2019.

The city learned about the plans after McLeod talked with EJI Executive Director Bryan Stevenson, who he said "was talking about the overwhelming success that they have had with the memorial and the museum.”

Stevenson recently said at a Chamber of Commerce event that estimates have shown that more than 200,000 visitors have gone through EJI's Legacy Museum and National Memorial for Peace and Justice since their opening in late April. The plans for the expansion breezed through council quickly, with members seemingly excited about the idea, especially after a spirited discussion about economic development earlier in the day at the work session.

search_result.title: America's lynching history is now online
search_result.text:
Jessica Guynn

USA TODAY





SAN FRANCISCO — Two years ago, a groundbreaking study on lynching documented the brutal mob violence that forced many African Americans to flee the south.

With help from Google, the racial justice group that published the study has transformed Lynching in America: Confronting the Legacy of Racial Terror into an interactive digital platform that combines historical data and personal stories so people can explore one of the darkest passages in the nation's history.

The goal is to spark a national dialogue about a subject that is too rarely discussed yet is crucial to understanding racism today, says Bryan Stevenson, founder and executive director of the Equal Justice Initiative and author of the best-selling book Just Mercy: A Story of Justice and Redemption.

Google.org, the Internet giant's philanthropic arm, also announced it's giving another $1 million to the Montgomery, Ala.-based Equal Justice Initiative to support its racial justice work. In 2015, Google.org gave $1 million to the Equal Justice Initiative to help fund a national memorial for lynching victims that the Equal Justice Initiative is building on six acres of vacant land in downtown Montgomery and a museum on the country's racial history planned for the group's headquarters that was once a slave warehouse.

"We want to change how we think about this era in America," Stevenson said.

Doria Dee Johnson's great-great-grandfather, Anthony Crawford, a father of 13 who started a school for black children and a successful businessman who owned 427 acres of prime cotton land in Abbeville, NC, was lynched in 1916 after arguing with a white store owner who did not want to pay him a fair price for his cotton seed.

Johnson, an activist and PhD candidate in American history at the University of Wisconsin, says the trauma of lynchings created silence. This new digital platform, with its capacity to reach millions, is now helping to break it.

RELATED:

Google gives $1M to Bryan Stevenson's racial justice effort

Google pledges $11.5M to fight racial bias in policing, sentencing

Bryan Stevenson to Silicon Valley: Go into communities

Policing in America

Black troops as much as twice as likely to be punished by commanders, courts

Visitors to the website can search a map of 4,300 lynchings in 20 states and hear how Elizabeth Lawrence, a school teacher in Alabama, was murdered in 1933 for reprimanding white schoolchildren for throwing rocks at her. Or how in 1893, 17-year-old Henry Smith, suspected of killing a white girl, was burned alive before a mob of 10,000 in Texas, his ashes and bones sold as souvenirs.

Another map shows the seismic population shift of the Great Migration as families were forced to leave to escape racial violence. A century ago nearly all African Americans lived in the South. By 1970 most lived outside of the South, many of them in industrial cities in the North and the West.

Oral histories, and a short documentary Uprooted, told from the perspective of descendants, examine how the terror of the past lives on for generations of African-American families. A high school lesson plan brings together findings from the lynching report with content from the digital platform to show how lynchings enforced decades of racial segregation.

"I just know that we have to keep remembering, to keep telling the story," says Tarabu Betserai Kirkland recounts during one of the oral histories.

His 109-year-old mother and her family had to leave their home and everything they owned in Mississippi in 1915 when she was seven years old because of a lynching threat, only to be terrorized by race riots and white vigilantes in Illinois and chased out of Ohio by klansmen who burned a cross on their lawn as she hid under the bed. A family friend, John Hartfield, who decided to return to Mississippi, was hung and shot before his body was burned before a mob of 10,000 in 1919.

"How do you get through that if you don't confront history?" Kirkland said.

For five years, the Equal Justice Initiative combed through accounts in local newspapers, court records and historical archives and conducted interviews with survivors and the descendants of victims to identify every lynching that took place in 20 states, uncovering some 800 more than previously found.

After the report was published, Stevenson says his group heard from hundreds of people whose family members were victims of lynchings and from people whose families participated in those lynchings.

The study is part of the Equal Justice Initiative's push to trace the roots of racial inequality in the United States from slavery to mass incarceration.

Stevenson says today's police shootings of unarmed African-American men and the mass incarceration of black people are a legacy of slavery and lynching. Black people are seen through a lens of racial difference that presumes their guilt, resulting in wrongful arrests, convictions and death sentences, he says.

"I think our history has created a kind of smog that we all breathe in. We don't even talk about the fact that we are living in a polluted environment that has been corrupted by this history of all kinds of racial inequality," Stevenson says.

Google says it worked with the Equal Justice Initiative to create an online space for people to reflect and learn.

"It was really important to take this data, almost 4,300 human lives lost in this era, and visualize it in a way where it was clear that each data point on this map is a human being, is a family, a broken family," said Nick Carbonaro, the project creative lead from Google.

More than a century ago, Shirah Dedman's great-grandfather, Thomas Miles, a black business owner in Shreveport, La., acquitted by a judge of writing letters to a white woman, was grabbed outside the courthouse by an angry mob and killed. Fear drove his family to Los Angeles.

Dedman and her family's journey back to Louisiana, for the first time since her great-grandfather was lynched there, is the subject of Uprooted, a six-minute documentary film on the new website.

A filmmaker in California, Dedman says her mother first told her how her great-grandfather died when Dedman was working on a family tree project in the third grade. Her family has no photographs of him, only a quarter-inch-thick report from the Equal Justice Initiative on how in 1912 he was strung up, strangled and shot. Her grandfather was six years old at the time.

"I am really hoping that sharing my family's story will help," Dedman says. "The only way we are going to heal as a people and as a nation is to confront what has happened to us."

In January, as a Google film crew trailed them, Dedman walked in her great-grandfather's footsteps with her mother and aunt, from the empty, overgrown lot where his home once stood to the spot on main street where he ran a small business to the old tree in a lonely field off a busy highway where her great-grandfather was hung. Dedman says as she approached the tree, her chest felt heavy and she couldn't catch her breath.

"I don't know what he looks like. Nobody knows what he looks like. But I could still see him. I could imagine him," she says. "You can imagine this man being hoisted up and knowing he's losing his life and that he has a baby and a wife at home."

Dedman wrapped her arms around the tree trunk. Her mother and aunt filled two glass jars with soil, one for the family to keep, the other for a national memorial. The jars are labeled with the names of the victims, the location of the lynchings and the dates of their deaths.

Dedman says as she looked at the spot where her family once lived in Shreveport, tears filled her eyes but her mother was smiling.

"It looked like you were home," she told her mother afterwards. Her mother responded: "I felt like I was home."

Follow USA TODAY senior technology writer Jessica Guynn on Twitter @jguynn

search_result.title: Ivey touts tourism growth, defends abortion law
search_result.text:
Alabama Gov. Kay Ivey on Monday revealed a surge in spending by tourists here in 2018, while dismissing concerns that backlash to Alabama’s restrictive new abortion law could slow that momentum.

About 27.7 million people visited the state last year and spent $15.5 billion, according to figures from the state Tourism Department. Spending grew 1.5% from 2017, and it’s up 67% in the past decade.

Tourism now accounts for 7.3% of Alabama’s GDP and supports nearly 200,000 jobs.

“The very fact that Alabama has seen increased tourism year after year for the past five or six years … speaks volumes,” Ivey said, when asked about a push on social media to boycott the state.

She also said she has not seen any push back to the new law from big businesses within the state “and I don’t expect to.”

The governor signed a bill into law last week that would criminalize nearly all abortions once it goes into effect in November. It’s expected to face a legal fight that the law’s supporters hope will end in the U.S. Supreme Court overturning Roe v. Wade.

More:After Alabama abortion ban bill passes, donations roll in for local advocacy groups

The move led to online backlash and calls for a boycott of the state and its products. President Donald Trump tweeted that he is in favor of exceptions for rape and incest victims. The Alabama law does not include such exemptions.

More:She had an illegal abortion after being raped as a 13-year-old. To her, Alabama's abortion ban 'an abomination'

“The bill passed the house and senate overwhelmingly, and the amendment to include exceptions was defeated,” Ivey said. “So the legislature has spoken and underscores the sanctity of life that the people of Alabama value so highly.”

Hundreds marched Sunday to oppose the ban during a rally in downtown Montgomery, a place that led the state’s major areas in tourism growth last year.

Montgomery County’s 15% year-over-year growth was “staggering,” state Tourism Director Lee Sentell said. He said he couldn’t remember any year in which a major Alabama county had such a spike in growth.

Travel-related employment in Montgomery County was up 12.6% last year. And the city has sold nearly 25,000 more hotel room nights so far this year than at the same point last year, said Ron Simmons of the Montgomery Area Chamber of Commerce.

Sentell pointed to the work done by the Equal Justice Initiative, which opened a museum and memorial to lynching victims in 2018.

More:One year later, EJI plans new sites after launching memorial to lynching victims

“EJI is responsible for a lot of that,” Sentell said. “People are coming from all over the country, all over the world. People who would never have come to Alabama before because they felt like they didn’t have a really good reason, because of what Bryan Stevenson and his group has done.

"It’s the only place in the world where you can come and get this story. We owe a lot of this growth to Bryan Stevenson.”

Statewide, the numbers continue to rise. Sentell said Alabama has seen 10 percent growth in spending by tourists since Oct. 1.

You can read the full impact study at tourism.alabama.gov/reports.

search_result.title: EJI plans new sites a year after launching memorial to lynching victims
search_result.text:
Bryan Stevenson knew a national memorial to lynching victims and a museum dedicated to the legacy of slavery wouldn’t be an easy thing to see. But he thought it was important, so he hoped people would make the trip to Montgomery to visit and learn.

More than 400,000 came in the first year, from around the world.

On the first anniversary of the memorial and museum, Stevenson’s Equal Justice Initiative is busy opening two new sites in Montgomery and planning memorials for 1,600 more lynching victims, all while adjusting to the huge crowds. “We didn’t plan on a lot of things because we didn’t anticipate this kind of response,” Stevenson said. “I mean, we hoped for it, but we didn’t plan on it. So, it’s been really exciting, but challenging.”

They’ve bought the 401 N. Perry St. site next to Riverwalk Stadium and are building an expansive facility there to streamline things. EJI’s ticket center and its gift shop and café, which are housed in separate spaces, will move to the new building. There’ll be expanded shuttle service, it’ll have parking for visitors, and there are plans to bring in a new restaurant.

“If you have 3,000 people visiting the sites during the day, they have to have places to eat,” Stevenson said. “So, we’re going to try to bring some added opportunities for food, not just for our visitors but for everybody in downtown Montgomery.”

The building’s focal point will be a tribute to 1,600 more lynching victims.

EXCLUSIVE COVERAGE: Legacy of Lynchings: America's history of racial terror

The hanging pillars of The National Memorial for Peace and Justice, which is a little less than a mile away, honors those who were lynched from 1877 to 1950. The new building will focus on people who were lynched from 1865 to 1877.

On Monday, EJI will dedicate a separate memorial to people lynched in the 1950s. Some of the victims’ family members plan to attend the dedication.

It stands outside the newly opened Peace and Justice Memorial Center, across the street from the original memorial. EJI said the center is meant to be a place where people can learn more about the history of race in America as well as the work of EJI itself.

More:EJI lynching memorial: A place of healing in the Heart of Dixie

It’s been 30 years since Stevenson founded what became EJI in Montgomery to provide legal assistance to death row inmates, the mentally ill, children being prosecuted as adults and others in need of help. Its advocacy work has saved innocent people from death row and helped change sentencing guidelines for children nationwide.

Much of that happened after the organization lost its federal funding in 1994. It relaunched operations as a nonprofit and survived on donations from what Stevenson called some “remarkable people” over the next decade. “I’ve always understood that justice is a constant struggle and that we weren’t going to be able to do anything that would help people if we weren’t willing to engage in that struggle,” he said. “We certainly had a lot of ups and downs financially.”

Public financial forms show those ups and downs, with the EJI mostly hovering around $3 million in revenue and assets through 2013. By the end of 2016, the most recent forms available, that had jumped to nearly $40 million in revenue and more than $57 million in assets. That was two years before the opening of the memorial and museum.

Stevenson said the past few years haven’t always made it easy to tackle the legal work.

“It’s been great that we’ve had so many people respond, but in honesty it’s actually made things harder because we’re now trying to manage these incredibly significant cultural spaces,” he said. “… And now we’re in the midst of preparing to manage this level of interest for the long term, which is a really exciting opportunity.”

That extends to the city as a whole, and particularly Montgomery’s redeveloped downtown.

Local attractions are seeing a surge in visitors while the city continues to lead the state in hotel occupancy rates and room demand. That last part isn’t necessarily a good thing — Stevenson and city leaders agree that the area needs more hotels. “The good news is we have some coming online,” said Dawn Hathcock of the Montgomery Area Chamber of Commerce.

More:Scarred by interstate, Cottage Hill ready for rebirth with EJI memorial

Four are under construction in the blocks around EJI’s facilities, and the area has seen a massive influx of investment and construction in the past decade, including new stores, restaurants and historic attractions.

Other problems remain. “We’ve got a lot of buildings that are unoccupied. We have a lot of spaces that are not utilized. We have a lot of real estate that doesn’t actually contribute to life in the city, either residential or commercial. We haven’t really created the optics that I think we want people to have when they drive into downtown Montgomery off of the interstate,” Stevenson said. “And those opportunities are opportunities that communities all across the country are having to wrestle with.

“A lot of what we’re doing was made harder by the absence of sort of a commitment to a downtown infrastructure that is alive and active, that’s not dormant and just sitting there for decades.”

Hathcock compared the infrastructure challenges to the ones that Austin, Texas, and Nashville, Tennessee, dealt with when those cities had to adjust to a sudden downtown boom. “It’s a good problem to have, but you have to manage it,” she said.

Still, Stevenson said Montgomery seems to be going in the right direction, and that it’s a direction that can serve as a lesson for other places, one about physical and social change.

“If you don’t get to the truth of (history), then you’re not going to create the kind of honest engagement that people need and want. That’s why we’ve tried not to shy away from the historical work we’ve been doing, even when they’re difficult and challenging,” Stevenson said. “But I think that has added interest in what’s going on in Montgomery. It’s enhanced the experience of people who come here in ways I think we should all be proud of.

“There’s a lot of untapped potential that our region offers people in all walks of life. We’ve got a military base, we’ve got state government, we have this rich history, we have beautiful natural resources. We have a community of people who care about service and sharing. All of those elements are critical to create a thriving space. We just have to take advantage of that.”

Brian Edwards contributed to this report.

search_result.title: Obama appoints task force on police practices
search_result.text:
David Jackson

USA TODAY

President Obama appointed members of a task force Thursday assigned to recommend police practices that can improve relations between officers and the people they serve, particularly in minority communities.

The president signed an executive order Thursday creating the Task Force on 21st Century Policing.

The task force, which includes officials from law enforcement, legal, academic, civil rights and non-profit organizations, will study methods that are working in different places and report back to Obama by March 2. The task force will terminate 30 days after it submits its report.

In the wake of protests over police killings of suspects, Obama is looking for ways to improve the criminal justice system and to "fortify public trust in it," White House senior adviser Valerie Jarrett said.

Obama created the task force amid demonstrations across the country after grand juries in Ferguson, Mo., and Staten Island, N.Y., declined to indict police officers in connection with the deaths of African American males.

In announcing the plan on Dec. 1, Obama said the group will "reach out and listen to law enforcement, and community activists and other stakeholders," and make recommendations on the best ways to promote working together.

"How do they create accountability?" Obama said. "How do they create transparency? How do they create trust; and how can we at the federal level work with the state and local communities to make sure that some of those best practices get institutionalized."

The task force will be chaired by Charles Ramsey, the police commissioner in Philadelphia, and Laurie Robinson, a former assistant attorney general who is now a professor at George Mason University in Fairfax, Va.

Ron Davis, director of the Justice Department's Community Oriented Policing Services Office, will serve as the group's executive director.

Other task force members:

• Jose Lopez, the lead organizer at Make the Road New York (MRNY), a Brooklyn-based non-profit community organization focused on civil rights, education changes and combating poverty.

• Bryan Stevenson, founder and executive director of the Equal Justice Initiative (EJI), a private, non-profit organization headquartered in Montgomery, Ala.

• Brittany Packnett, the executive director of Teach For America in St. Louis, Mo., which is near Ferguson.

• Susan Rahr, executive director of the Washington State Criminal Justice Training Commission.

• Tracey Meares, the Walton Hale Hamilton Professor of Law at Yale Law School.

• Constance Rice, a civil rights attorney and co-director of the Advancement Project, an organization she co-founded in 1999. In 2003, Rice was selected to lead a panel that investigated the largest police corruption scandal in Los Angeles Police Department history.

• Roberto Villaseñor, chief of police in Tucson, Ariz.

• Sean Smoot, director and chief counsel for the Police Benevolent & Protective Association of Illinois and the Police Benevolent Labor Committee

• Cedric L. Alexander, the deputy chief operating officer for public safety in DeKalb County, Ga, and also national president of the National Organization of Black Law Enforcement Executives.

search_result.title: Colin Kaepernick: Harvard presents ex-NFL QB with black history ...
search_result.text:
Former NFL quarterback Colin Kaepernick was among eight people saluted by Harvard University on Thursday for contributions to black history and culture.

All eight recipients of the prestigious W.E.B. Du Bois Medal were honored in a ceremony held Thursday afternoon by the Hutchins Center for African and African American Research at Harvard "in recognition of their contributions to African and African American culture and the life of the mind."

As requested by Kaepernick, his speech at the ceremony was not broadcast live (there was a live stream of the event available). In his speech, Kaepernick encouraged further protests against racial inequality.

"I feel like it's not only my responsibility, but all our responsibilities as people that are in positions of privilege, in positions of power, to continue to fight for them and uplift them, empower them," Kaepernick said. "Because if we don't we become complicit in the problem."

Here is a full transcript of his speech:

NFL STATS CENTRAL: The latest NFL scores, schedules, odds, stats and more.

The other honorees were Dave Chappelle, comedian; Kenneth Chenault, chairman and a managing director of General Catalyst; Shirley Ann Jackson, president of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute; Pamela Joyner, founder of Avid Partners, LLC; psychologist and author Florence Ladd; Bryan Stevenson, founder and executive director of the Equal Justice Initiative; and artist Kehinde Wiley.

Past award winners include Muhammad Ali (2015) and Maya Angelou (2014).

Kaepernick — who spent six seasons with the San Francisco 49ers, including helping lead the team to Super Bowl XLVII — created a heated national debate when he began kneeling during the The Star-Spangled Banner in 2016 to protest police brutality and social injustice.

Two seasons after he began kneeling to protest police and racial injustice, Kaepernick is still out of the NFL. His actions spurred dozens of other NFL players to protest. President Donald Trump has fanned the hot-button issue and politicized the peaceful protest while deriding the NFL from his Twitter account. USA TODAY analysis of Sunday Night Football viewership revealed that player protests during the anthem have had little to no effect on the league's TV ratings.

Kaepernick was the centerpiece of Nike’s 30th anniversary of their “Just Do It” campaign, and his efforts earned him Amnesty International’s Ambassador of Conscience award in April.

Contributing: The Associated Press.

search_result.title: Ten names making it happen in Montgomery
search_result.text:
Here are some of the people, groups and organizations helping to shape the future of Montgomery and the River Region.

Bryan Stevenson

The eyes of the world turned to Montgomery when Stevenson’s Equal Justice Initiative opened a memorial and museum here that pays tribute to lynching victims and traces the history of slavery and racial inequality in America. Stevenson’s work has helped establish the city as a focal point for tough discussions and social progress in a changing nation.

Charles Lee

After building his business from a hot dog cart to a popular restaurant, this Chicago transplant started a mentorship program and community center for kids in one of the poorest areas of Montgomery. He now spends most of his time working with them to explore their interests, develop their skills and help prepare them for jobs. There’s a “Jesus Dog” on the menu at his restaurant. Order it and you don’t actually get a hot dog. Instead the money goes to the youth program.

Downtown Business Association

This group of entrepreneurs, artists and local businesspeople has grown from about a dozen to nearly 150 in just a few years, alongside a resurgent downtown Montgomery. It’s continued to feed those changes by encouraging local owners to partner and share ideas while directly backing events that support a subculture suddenly exploding with young residents and tourists. One of their initiatives created a fund that awards money each month to help make improvements happen.

Hyundai Motor Manufacturing Alabama

During a lean time for the South Korean automaker, and for the industry in general, the local Hyundai assembly plant slowed its production line to keep thousands of full-time workers employed while it adjusts to an SUV-hungry market. Thousands more people continue to work at suppliers across central Alabama that build parts for the plant, and high school and college students here are training to fill some of the employment gaps.

Leadership Montgomery

Through its classes for young professionals and longtime community leaders, this organization has brought people together, helped bring change to the region and tackled some its toughest problems. Bridging races, ethnicities and other differences, the groups come up with ideas for ways to improve the city and help implement them. One class spawned a downtown New Year’s Eve bash that’s become one of the city’s most popular events. Others have worked on long-term solutions for issues in public schools.

LEDIC Realty

This Tennessee-based development and management company has launched $37 million effort to reawaken an iconic, 19th century facility built by town founder Daniel Pratt at the heart of Prattville. After years of sitting dormant, an industrial complex nicknamed “the gin shop” is being converted into 147 unique loft apartments. Despite delays, the plan has energized the community’s downtown and created an influx of more business.

Mark and Sarah Buller

The owners of New York’s MarJam Supply Co. are behind a plan to renovate and revitalize a stretch of Dexter Avenue, one of the nation’s most historic streets. The first step made a splashy debut this spring when the former Kress Department Store reopened as a modern loft development, retail center and connecting point for the city’s past and future. More projects are on the way.

University of Alabama Birmingham Medical School

With the average age of local doctors on the rise, a branch campus opened here in 2014, working with Baptist Health in Montgomery to train the next generation. That happened in part because data shows physicians are more likely to practice in the area where they trained, even when they could make more money elsewhere. Meanwhile, a network of donors stepped up to offer scholarships that encourage those students to fill gaps in the local healthcare landscape, and a clinic opened as part of the partnership between Baptist and UAB.

Montgomery Area Chamber of Commerce

As one of the most active chambers in the Southeast, this massive group unites local businesspeople to work together in almost every area of River Region development. That includes recruiting new companies and keeping existing ones happy, holding educational programs for startups and working with the area’s military community and minority business owners. Regular events bring together elected leaders and others to discuss problems and launch new ideas.

search_result.title: National Civil Rights Museum honors 7 at Freedom Awards
search_result.text:
John Biefuss, The (Memphis) Commercial Appeal

MEMPHIS — An "Equal Justice" crusader. A broadcast journalist. A federal judge. A Nobel Peace Prize laureate. A WNBA player. A lawyer whose clients have included the families of Trayvon Martin and Michael Brown. A former governor.

With the possible exception of longtime television anchor Soledad O'Brien, the seven men and women honored Thursday by the National Civil Rights Museum weren't mainstream celebrities. Past recipients of the museum's annual Freedom Award have included Nelson Mandela, Bill Clinton, Sidney Poitier, Stevie Wonder, the Dalai Lama, and at least three people so famous — Bono, Oprah and Usher — they don't even need last names, but the sold-out 25th anniversary awards ceremony at the 2,000-seat Cannon Center for the Performing Arts focused for the most part on human rights activists whose achievements have surpassed their popular recognition.

"There's not that 'one name,' but what we have are people who have worked really hard and continue to work really hard in the justic arena," said Terri Lee Freeman, president of the museum, constructed around what more than one attendee referred to as the "sacred ground" of the Lorraine Motel, where Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was murdered on April 4, 1968.

How to navigate the Smithsonian's terrific new African American museum

"I feel the soul of Martin Luther King around me everywhere here," said first-time Memphis visitor and Freedom Award honoree Tawakkol Karman of Yemen, winner of the 2011 Nobel Peace Prize. "He was our soul, our spirit in all 'Arab Spring' countries."

Part celebration, part call to action, the Freedom Awards ceremony was a largely riveting production, thanks mainly to the relatively brief but eloquent speeches — inspiring, humbling and chastening in equal measure — of the award recipients.

The roll call of honorees included:

• Women's National Basketball Association star Swin Cash, 37, a member of two University of Connecticut NCAA basketball championship teams and 2012 Olympic gold medalist who used her popularity as an athlete to promote women's rights, protest the shooting deaths of black men and support the unionization of college athletes.

• Florida attorney Benjamin Crump, 47, in the news in recent months for taking on high-profile, pro bono cases involving Trayvon Martin, Michael Brown, Tamir Rice, and other black men, teens and pre-teens killed in confrontations with law enforcement.

• Tawakkol Karman, 37, of Yemen, recipient of the 2011 Nobel Peace Prize for her non-violent "Arab Spring" activism and her role in promoting women's rights in the Middle East.

• Sixth Circuit U.S. Court of Appeals Judge Damon Jerome Keith, 94, a federal judge since the Lyndon Johnson administration. Keith is revered for historic rulings involving public housing, education access and — in the Nixon era — illegal wire-tapping. (Keith was the only honoree unable to attend the event.)

• Soledad O'Brien, 50, a longtime television journalist, anchor and producer whose credits include the multi-part CNN series Black in America.

• Social justice lawyer Bryan Stevenson, 56, founder and executive director of the Equal Justice Initiative, which advocates for prison reform and challenges bias in the criminal justice system.

• Former Mississippi governor William F. Winter, 93, who challenged his state's long history of discrimination by fighting for public primary education and serving on the board of President Clinton's traveling forum on race relations, the "One America" initiative.

Before the ceremony, Crump said his tour of the museum Thursday made him realize the very direct connection between the sanitation strike in Memphis and the Black Lives Matter movement today. He said that when marchers wore "I AM A MAN" signs, they were asserting their own dignity and worth, "they were not saying that, 'You are a not a man.' With Black Lives Matter, they're not saying saying, 'Your life doesn't matter,' they're saying, 'Our lives matter.'"

At one point, host Michael Eric Dyson, an author and radio personality, led the crowd in a chant of "What do we want? Justice? When do we want it? Now!" The moment recognized this year's Freedom Awards theme — "And Justice For All" — while also enlisting the audience as participants in the evening's oratory.

Stevenson, who identified himself as the "great-grandson of enslaved people," said: "We are still not free in this country." He said America has failed to reckon with its identity as "a post-genocidal society" that "used the narrative of racial difference to justify the murder of millions of indigenous people ... and this same narrative of racial difference was used to justify ... the ideology of white supremacy that we made up to justify slavery." He said his narrative is "still alive," and the basis of laws and systems that promote poverty, ignorance and the mass incarceration of black men.

William Winter — the lone white award recipient — said he grew up as a beneficiary of this system. "I now look back in disbelief at the unfairness of the racist system of which I was part." During his speech, he warned against "political appeals based on racial demagoguery"; before the show he said: "I hope we elect a president next month who will bring us together."

Karman struck a similar note when she accepted her award: "For me, there is no boundary between a racist and a dictator. Racism and dictatorship need each other."

The awards event also included special recognition of "The Memphis 13," the African-American first-graders who desegregated the city's public schools on Oct. 3, 1961, when they began attending classes at formerly all-white Bruce, Gordon, Rozelle and Springdale elementary schools.

The Freedom Awards ceremony was just one part of a full day of activities for some of the honorees and museum officials. Several award recipients met with school students Thursday morning at Mississippi Boulevard Christian Church, while the ceremony was followed by a black-tie gala dinner at the Memphis Cook Convention Center.
